triples.name: Game theory
triples.relevance: Game theory is the central mathematical framework the paper uses to analyze stakeholder interactions in construction engineering and management

triples.name: Social network analysis
triples.relevance: SNA is the quantitative analytical method used to analyze game-theoretic interactions among CEM stakeholders and identify literature trends

triples.name: Conflict resolution
triples.relevance: One of the seven identified CEM applications where game theory is applied to resolve disputes among construction stakeholders

triples.name: Negotiation
triples.relevance: Bargaining and negotiations represent one of the seven primary applications of game theory in CEM covered in the survey

triples.name: Risk parity
triples.relevance: Risk allocation among CEM stakeholders is one of the seven identified applications of game-theoretic models

triples.name: Design-bid-build
triples.relevance: A traditional project delivery system examined in the survey as a context for game-theoretic analysis of CEM stakeholder interactions

triples.name: Public-private partnership
triples.relevance: A key project delivery system analyzed in the survey, with future need for expanded game-theoretic investigation across different PDS types

triples.name: Supply chain management
triples.relevance: Supply chains of multiagents are highlighted as an area needing future game-theoretic research for more adequate reflections of actual CEM interactions

triples.name: Strategic alliance
triples.relevance: Games featuring strategic alliances are identified as an important gap requiring future investigation for better modeling of actual CEM stakeholder interactions
